Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Reversible Solid Electrolyte Interface (SEI) Layers for Advanced Li-ion Batteries and Beyond

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although lithium ion batteries have been commercialized for consumer electronics, they still fall far behind the requirements needed for batteries used in long-range electric vehicles and large-scale renewable energy storage. There is a need to improve the energy densities of lithium ion batteries and to research "beyond lithium ion" battery technologies that employ high-capacity but low-cost materials such as silicon, oxygen or sulfur electrodes. Almost all battery chemistries in electrochemical energy storage cells operate beyond the stability limits of the electrolytes, substance that produce an electrically conducting solution when dissolved. These battery cells operate in many cases because electrode material-electrolyte reactions result in the formation of a protective material layer on the electrode material, called a solid-electrolyte interface layer. The mechanical and chemical reactivity properties of this protective layer dictate the energy, power and the long-term cycling stability of the battery system; however, fundamental knowledge on the formation of this protective layer is lacking. This research project is investigating a new solid-electrolyte interface layer formation mechanism that will enable design solutions for many of the performance limitations of batteries. The research outcomes of this project are being integrated into energy-themed educational activities for students to study science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) subjects.

This collaborative research project between research groups at the University and Arkansas and the University of Michigan seeks a fundamentally new solid-electrolyte interface formation mechanism by using silicon/electrolyte interfaces as a model system. Intensive electrochemical characterizations are being conducted by testing silicon film electrodes in various concentrated electrolytes to understand the coordination environments of lithium cations in the bulk electrolytes and its implications on the solid-electrolyte interface layer compositions. In situ atomic force microscopy is being employed to probe the formation and evolution of solid-electrolyte interface layers on silicon surfaces in a cell. Theoretical simulations are being combined with material characterizations to advance the fundamental understanding of solid-electrolyte interface layers derived from concentrated electrolytes. The research project is designed to test a new theory to control the interfacial properties between electrodes and electrolyte, one that is broadly applicable to battery technologies and many other energy storage and conversion systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Li-ionbatteries are a type of rechargeable battery in which Li-ions move from the negative electrode to the positive electrode during discharge and move back during the charging process. Due to the following advantages: high energy density, tiny memory effect, low self-charge and high portability. Li-ion batteries have been applied in home electronics, portable electronics, electric vehicle batteries, andaerospace engineering. One of the critical phenomenain a Li-ion battery, which strongly influences its stability and performance, is the formation of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI). The SEI is a passivating film that forms on the carbon anode. During the first charge of the battery, Li-ionssolvated, by solvent molecules, approach the surface of the graphite. After losing the solvation shell, the Li-ionsintercalate the graphite sheets. The SEI can prevent the electrolyte from further degradation and protect the graphite anode from decomposition. However, since the formation of the SEI irreversibly consumes Li and electrons, the capacity of the battery will suffer a permanentloss during the first charge cycle. Therefore, to obtain a deeper understanding and develop moreadvanced Li-ionbatteries, the formation mechanisms, composition and stability of the SEI must be systematically investigated.

 

The major goals of the project are performing the mesoscale (phase field) modeling to understand the basic mechanisms of the reversible SEI in the lithium ion battery with concentrated electrolyte. The low-level atomic simulations will also be applied to provide basic parameters for mesoscale modeling calculation. The current experiment study of reversible SEI in the lithium ion battery with concentrated electrolyte has been reviewed. In order to conduct the computational research on the reversible SEI, the current state of computational studies on the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) in lithium ion battery has been reviewed. Based on ab initio molecular dynamics simulations, a phase field model has been developed to study the mechanisms of classical SEI formation and the reversible SEI in lithium-ion batteries, with input data obtained via ab initiocalculations from both literature and calculated at the University of Michigan. Three elements: the functionalization of the graphite anode edge, the solution of lithium salt in the solution, and the choice of the organic solvent which will influence the SEI formation have been discussed. It is of interest to note the critical issue is identified to be the definition of over-potential, which does not describe stability of the electrolyte and SEI phases. We propose a correct approach and find that thedetailed information on reversible and irreversible reactions involvedis critical for modeling SEI formation and elucidating composition dependence of its reversibility. The SEI model is validated by experiments and the results provide a theoretical base for further developingmoreadvanced Li-ionbatteries.
